ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course used to be called "Model Organisms in Biological Research," and that's essentially what it's about. We learned important biological techniques, like microscopy (light & dissection microscopes), pipetting, PCR & electrophoresis, and making genetic crosses through various model organisms ranging from bacteria to vertebrates (and DNA from our own epithelial cells!).

I was definitely introduced to some skills and organisms that I had not worked with before (ELISA, working with Drosophila, etc.). I also learned how to write a lab report in the correct order beginning with constructing figures.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Great overview of the model organisms in biological research, spanned molecular, cellular, and developmental biology, as well as organisms in different kingdoms. Instructions on lab activity and lab reports were clear. Feedback was kind of timely, but I would appreciate it if I could get it sooner. Weaknesses: Could have been clearer on the "Design Your Own Experiment" part at the beginning of the semester. Give more information about what exactly the student needs to do, and perhaps include some questions to guide them.

I think a big strength is the resources that we were given for each lab assignment and the pre lab lecture that Dr. Moreno gave us. One weakness was that sometimes the direction or order of the lab was not clear/deviated from the packet.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I took it with BIOL 101/102 as a first-year and don't regret doing so, but don't feel like you have to take it if you're taking the introductory bio sequence because there's a decent number of upperclassmen. (And don't take it if you're taking another lab like gen-chem or orgo.) That being said, it was extremely informative and I got a good overview of biological research through reading about a variety of model organisms. Some parts of it, such as embryo development and the occasional requirement of statistical tests in lab reports, have been a bit challenging. The workload was definitely smaller than most one-credit courses, but it's a half-credit so... Both Prof Moreno and my TF Kelly were very approachable and genuinely cared about their students. AND it's one of the few STEM courses that give you (half of) a writing credit!
Yes! Dr. Moreno is very helpful and knowledgeable, and you definitely gain alot of new and valuable skills from this lab.
